moves.1. e4 c5 2. d3: White looks to want to play the closed Sicilian
moves.2... Nc6 3. Nf3 d6 4. Be2 g6 5. O-O Bg7: Relieving the dsb from the protection of b2
moves.6... Nf6 7. Re1 O-O 8. b3 Be6 9. Bb2 Nd7: As black I feel that I should try to break though queen side with this set up.
moves.10. Nbd2 b5 11. d4: White puts up a direct challenge to the center.
moves.11... b4: Not sure I made the best mover here point being d5 bxc3 allowing a decent threat should white continue (13. dxe6 cxb2 14. Rb1 with a passed pawn now in great position fxe6 though the position would be unclear and imbalanced.)
moves.12. Rc1: White protects my threat and revives his threat.
moves.12... d5: Giving direct challenge things will get messy.
moves.14. Bb5 dxe4: An interesting choice here by me sacing my rook to try to gain some initiative.
moves.18. Qc2 bxc3 19. Ne4 Qd3: Bf5 may have been more effective.  Continue with the direct challenges.
moves.24. Qxc2 Rxc2 25. Ra1 Bf5 26. Bd5 Bd3: Move gives the bishop plenty of life and keep the king out of the game for the moment.
moves.29... Kf8 30. h4 Ke7 31. g4: Here f6 or h6 might have come in handy
moves.31... Kd6 32. g5: locking my pawns on f7 and h7 very good move.
moves.36. Ke3 Bd5 37. Kd3: Now the position i drawn and will become apparent in a few moves
moves.37... a5 38. Kc3 Be4 39. Be2 Bc6: No progress can be made for either side.
